title: 105_hr2408
content: The "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students by providing productive activities during after school hours. Congress finds that today's youth face increased social risks, spend more unsupervised time alone, and are at higher risk of violence during after school hours. The Act sets goals to address these challenges. The goals of the "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" include increasing academic success, improving students' skills, promoting safe environments, preparing for workforce participation, and providing alternatives to negative activities. The Act defines terms like "school" and "Secretary" and authorizes a program for awarding grants to schools for specific activities. The "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" requires schools receiving grants to carry out specific activities like mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training. Schools may also conduct drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities. These activities must be provided after regular school hours and tailored to the needs of the population, students, and community. Activities should take place in a school building or designated public facility. The "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" requires schools to carry out specific activities tailored to the needs of the population, students, and community. Activities should be conducted in a school building or designated public facility, and schools are encouraged to seek volunteers, donations of computer equipment, and collaborate with state and local park and recreation agencies to avoid duplication of activities. Each school seeking a grant under this Act must submit an application to the Secretary, detailing how they will meet the goals, involve various stakeholders, administer activities, avoid duplication with other programs, outline funding sources, and secure non-Federal funding. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2002.
